Title: Incorporating uncertainty measurement in the International Diabetes Federation Diabetes Atlas methodology for estimating global and national prevalence of diabetes in adults
Journal: Archives of Public Health
Publication Year: 2015
Diseases: Diabetes
Location: Brussels, Belgium and Suwon, South Korea
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 0
Incorporating uncertainty measurements in the International Diabetes Federation Diabetes Atlas methodology for estimating global and national prevalence of diabetes in adults is crucial for enhancing the reliability and transparency of the estimates. This allows for better comparisons with other data sources and over time. The uncertainty interval was found to be around 0.9% wide on a global level.

metadata.text:
Title: The “Podiatry Diabetes Model”- an example of an organised approach to the podiatric care of people with diabetes in regional Victoria
Journal: Journal of Foot and Ankle Research
Publication Year: 2011
Diseases: Diabetes, Diabetes-related foot complications
Location: Greater Bendigo region of Victoria, Australia
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 576
People with diabetes seen within the Podiatry Diabetes Model are being seen by the most appropriate podiatry service available according to their risk of future diabetes-related foot morbidity. The model highlights successful cross-organization collaboration and has the potential for replication in other regions. Further research will focus on assessing the model's impact on future incidence rates of ulceration and amputation in the region.

Title: Frequency of dawn phenomenon and its associations with age, HbA1c and diabetes duration in Japanese type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) using the continuous glucose monitoring system (CGMS)
Journal: International Journal of Pediatric Endocrinology
Publication Year: 2013
Diseases: Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM)
Location: Japan
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 21
The frequency of the dawn phenomenon in Japanese individuals with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) was lower in this study compared to previous findings. The associations with longer diabetes duration and advanced age suggest a connection with poor glycemic control. Therefore, adjusting continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion (CSII) using continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) may be more beneficial than increasing pre-meal boluses.

Title: Cyclical variation in the national incidence of childhood type 1 diabetes in Australia (2000 - 2011)
Journal: International Journal of Pediatric Endocrinology
Publication Year: 2015
Diseases: Childhood type 1 diabetes
Location: Australia-wide
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 11575
The main conclusion of the research article is that there was no linear increase in the annual overall incidence of childhood type 1 diabetes in Australia from 2000 to 2011. A 5-year cyclical pattern was detected, pointing towards fluctuations in disease occurrence and suggesting a role for environmental factors in the development of childhood type 1 diabetes in Australia.

Title: A lack of association between vitamin d-binding protein and 25-hydroxyvitamin d concentrations in pediatric type 1 diabetes without microalbuminuria
Journal: International Journal of Pediatric Endocrinology
Publication Year: 2015
Diseases: Type 1 Diabetes
Location: Seoul and the Gyeonggi-Do in Korea
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 74
The main conclusion of the research paper is that there is no association between vitamin D-binding protein and 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations in pediatric type 1 diabetes patients without microalbuminuria. Urinary VDBP loss was increased in these patients, but it did not correlate with serum 25-OHD levels. Factors like daylight outdoor hours and vitamin D intake were more influential in determining 25-OHD levels in this population.

Title: Analysis of insulin pump settings in children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes mellitus
Journal: International Journal of Pediatric Endocrinology
Publication Year: 2015
Diseases: Type 1 diabetes mellitus
Location: Sydney, NSW, Australia
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 292
The main conclusion of the research paper is that insulin pump therapy requires ongoing adjustments, and only a minority of patients achieve the desired glycaemic targets. The study emphasizes the importance of factors like the number of daily boluses, frequency of blood glucose testing, and insulin sensitivity in influencing HbA1c levels and weight control. These insights into real-life carbohydrate ratio and insulin sensitivity factors can potentially optimize pump therapy in the future.

The study concludes that children with Type 2 diabetes mellitus had poor metabolic control, as evidenced by a mean HbA1c of 9.7%, and early complications were already apparent after a relatively short follow-up duration of 3.6 years. Title: Association of Vitamin D3 levels with glycemic control in Type 2 diabetes subjects from Gujarati population-India
Journal: Molecular Cytogenetics
Publication Year: 2014
Diseases: Type 2 Diabetes
Location: Gujarat, India
Gender: Both
Sample size: 508
Present study demonstrates the high prevalence (66.34%) of Vitamin D3 deficiency in Gujarati population from India, more so for subjects with T2D. It is likely that Vitamin D3 has a role in regulating insulin sensitization; resulting in poor glycemic control in subjects with low Vitamin D3 levels. This study also indicates that females are likely to be at a higher risk for Vitamin D3 deficiency compared to male in T2D and control subjects.

metadata.text:
Title: Effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on cardiac arrest resuscitation practices and outcomes in non-COVID-19 patients
Journal: Journal of Intensive Care
Publication Year: 2021
Diseases: In-hospital cardiac arrest (IHCA)
Location: Hong Kong SAR, China
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 629
The study concludes that changes in resuscitation practices during the COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on IHCA outcomes in non-COVID-19 patients. Despite adjustments for various factors, the pandemic was independently associated with lower rates of return of spontaneous circulation. This suggests that modifications in CPR procedures influenced cardiac arrest management and outcomes even in patients without COVID-19. The authors highlight the importance of adapting resuscitation protocols during pandemics to improve patient outcomes.

Title: Incidence and risk factors of peripheral nerve injuries 3 months after ICU discharge: a retrospective study comparing COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 critically ill survivors
Journal: Journal of Anesthesia, Analgesia and Critical Care
Publication Year: 2024
Diseases: Peripheral Nerve Injury (PNI), COVID-19
Location: Belgium
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 77
In the present cohort retrospectively assessed 3 months after a prolonged ICU stay, PNI symptoms were reported in at least one-third of the survivors, in similar proportion whether they suffered from severe COVID-19 or not. PNI symptoms did not seem to impact autonomy or health-related quality of life. Only the duration of mechanical ventilation was found to be a PNI risk factor.

Title: Acceptability of a COVID-19 pre-exposure prophylaxis trial with hydroxychloroquine in French healthcare workers during the first wave of COVID-19 pandemic
Journal: Trials
Publication Year: 2021
Diseases: COVID-19
Location: France
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 695
At the time of the survey, French healthcare workers showed a willingness to participate in a chemoprophylaxis trial with hydroxychloroquine, despite concerns about side effects. However, subsequent trials indicated that HCQ is unlikely to be effective as a prophylactic agent against COVID-19. The findings from the survey were crucial in the decision to start the trial. The paper concludes that while HCQ may not be effective, exploring other agents and regimens for prophylaxis remains important until vaccines are widely available.

Title: Friedreich ataxia in COVID-19 time: current impact and future possibilities
Journal: Cerebellum & Ataxias
Publication Year: 2021
Diseases: Friedreich ataxia (FA)
Location: IRCCS Bambino Gesù Children’s Hospital in Rome, Italy
Gender: FEMALE
Sample size: 20
The COVID-19 lockdown highlighted the critical need to enhance support for ataxic individuals through improved systems for remote physical activity and technology-based assistance. The study emphasized the importance of physical training for FA patients' overall health and the resilience demonstrated by these individuals in adopting home-based training strategies and technology tools during the crisis. The findings underscored the urgency to develop and enhance systems for home-based physical training and remote assessment for ataxic patients, especially in challenging circumstances like the COVID-19 pandemic.

Location: Kaiser Permanente Southern California (KPSC)
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 212000
The risk of new-onset lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI) following hospital discharge was substantial, particularly among individuals hospitalized for non-COVID-19 LRTI, and also for COVID-19 LRTI. Title: Leguminous allergy in a sample of children attending an outpatient allergy clinic
Journal: Clinical and Translational Allergy
Publication Year: 2015
Diseases: Leguminous allergy, Pea allergy, Chickpea allergy, Bean allergy, Anaphylaxis
Location: Portugal
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 6
In this sample of children with leguminous allergy, the study concludes that peas and chickpeas were responsible for most of the allergic reactions. The clinical features observed ranged from mild to severe, and the majority of the children were allergic to more than one type of leguminous food. The study also noted a high prevalence of multiple food allergies and allergic rhinitis among the participants. The reliability of prick to prick skin tests for diagnosing leguminous allergy was highlighted. The study provides valuable insights into the clinical aspects of leguminous allergy in children from Portugal.

Title: Soybean allergy in a population with a low prevalence of betulacae pollen allergy and a high soybean consumption
Journal: Clinical and Translational Allergy
Publication Year: 2011
Diseases: Soybean allergy, Betulacae pollen allergy
Location: Japan
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 21
A strong relationship between adult soybean allergy and sensitization to rGly m 4 was observed in this population with high soybean consumption. The level of IgE antibody to CAP-rGly m 4 was an effective tool in discriminating soybean allergy from general alder pollen-allergy. This result highlights the impact of respiratory allergy to pollen-derived cross-reactive allergens on the epidemics of adult plant food allergy, particularly in regions with high soybean consumption.

Title: 2078- Immunotherapy – 2078. Allergen-specific oral immunotherapy for peanut allergy: a Cochrane systematic review
Journal: World Allergy Organization Journal
Publication Year: 2013
Diseases: Peanut Allergy, Adverse Reactions, Immune Tolerance
Location: UK, Netherlands, Canada
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 25
We found one small RCT judged to be at low risk of bias which showed that peanut OIT can result in desensitisation in children, and that this is associated with evidence of concurrent immune-modulation. However, due to the risk of adverse reactions, especially mild ones, the research indicates that peanut OIT cannot currently be recommended for the management of patients with IgE-mediated peanut allergy, emphasizing the need for larger trials to assess safety, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness.

Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 25
We found one small RCT judged to be at low risk of bias which showed that peanut OIT can result in desensitisation in children, and that this is associated with evidence of concurrent immune-modulation. However, due to the risk of adverse reactions, especially mild ones, the research indicates that peanut OIT cannot currently be recommended for the management of patients with IgE-mediated peanut allergy, emphasizing the need for larger trials to assess safety, effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness.

metadata.text:
Title: Are there predictive symptoms/signs for a positive oral cow's milk challenge in patients suspected of cow's milk allergy?
Journal: World Allergy Organization Journal
Publication Year: 2015
Diseases: Cow's Milk Allergy (CMA)
Location: Federal University of Sao Paulo, Brazil
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 100
The study found that while cow’s milk allergy is frequently suspected in Brazilian children, only a small percentage actually confirmed the diagnosis. Specific symptoms like urticaria, pruritus, vomiting, rhinoconjunctivitis, and anaphylaxis were linked to a positive cow’s milk food challenge. However, no specific clinical characteristics were identified for predicting a positive challenge. This reaffirms the importance of conducting cow’s milk food challenges for the accurate diagnosis of cow’s milk allergy.

Title: EHMTI-0150. A controlled study of sleep in cluster headache patients.apo04
Journal: The Journal of Headache and Pain
Publication Year: 2014
Diseases: Cluster headache (CH)
Location: Denmark
Gender: Both
Sample size: 65
To date, this is the largest study of sleep in CH. REM-sleep is affected in CH which is in line with our current understanding of CH and newer studies indicating hypothalamic involvement in the regulation of this sleep stage. Further, we found fewer arousals in CH-patients as has been demonstrated in other headache disorders. Together, the findings support a central role of the hypothalamus and arousal systems in CH.

metadata.text:
Title: How much sleep apnea is too much?
Journal: Arthritis Research & Therapy
Publication Year: 2009
Diseases: Sleep apnea, Fibromyalgia
Location: Not Available
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 0
The conclusion of the article emphasizes the significance of considering even the lowest levels of sleep-disordered breathing when studying the role of disturbed sleep in conditions like fibromyalgia. It underscores the potential impact of even minimal levels of apnea-hypopnea events on the autonomic nervous system and advocates for thorough reporting of AHI in research related to pain syndromes. The key takeaway is that any number of sleep-disordered breathing events may have a non-trivial influence on the development and progression of conditions associated with chronic pain.

Title: The associations between physical activity, sedentary behaviour, and sleep with mortality and incident cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes and mental health in adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies
Journal: Journal of Activity, Sedentary and Sleep Behaviors
Publication Year: 2023
Diseases: Cardiovascular disease, Cancer, Diabetes, Mental health disorders (symptoms of depression and anxiety)
Location: USA, Australia, China, Finland, Spain, Sweden, Taiwan, UK
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 0
The research paper investigates the associations between physical activity, sedentary behavior, and sleep with mortality and incident cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, and mental health in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies. Main conclusion: High levels of physical activity may offset all-cause mortality risks associated with short sleep duration. Low levels of physical activity combined with short sleep duration and any level of physical activity in combination with long sleep duration appear to increase mortality risk.

metadata.text:
Title: Sleep as a vital sign
Journal: Sleep Science and Practice
Publication Year: 2023
Diseases: Insomnia, Obstructive Sleep Apnea
Location: Not Available
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 0
The main conclusion derived from the research paper is that integrating sleep assessment into routine clinical practice is crucial for improving patient outcomes. The authors argue for the importance of considering sleep as a vital sign and suggest implementing brief screening tools like the RU-SATED scale to identify potential sleep disorders in patients. The paper underscores the significant impact of untreated sleep problems on healthcare costs and individual health, advocating for the recognition of sleep as a fundamental aspect of overall health. The conclusion implies that with effective detection and treatment of sleep-related conditions, there will be a substantial positive impact on public health, emphasizing the need to prioritize sleep assessment and treatment in clinical settings.

As a result, the Editors-in-Chief no longer have confidence in the data."

Diseases: Colorectal cancer (CRC), Pseudomonas infection

Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 178
While a significant number of samples from cleaned endoscopes showed bacterial growth, pathogenic bacteria were only found in one sample, indicating a low but existing risk of transmission of infections. Diseases: Osteoporosis, Cardiovascular Disease, Stroke
Location: Toronto, Canada
Gender: FEMALE
Sample size: 0
Recent data from the Women's Health Initiative suggest that combined estrogen plus therapy increases the risk of stroke, coronary artery disease and breast cancer. This conclusion emphasizes the shift in recommendations regarding hormone therapy, no longer advocating its use for chronic disease prevention in asymptomatic women, and the need for further research into alternative treatments and educating healthcare providers and women on effective strategies for managing cardiovascular health during menopause.

metadata.text:
Title: The benefits and risks of menopause hormone therapy for the cardiovascular system in postmenopausal women: a systematic review and meta-analysis
Journal: BMC Women's Health
Publication Year: 2024
Diseases: Stroke, Venous Thromboembolism
Location: Not Available
Gender: Not Available
Sample size: 0
MHT in postmenopausal women improves FMD but does not reduce all-cause death or cardiovascular events. It is associated with increased risks of stroke and venous thromboembolism. Early initiation of MHT within 10 years after menopause shows better benefits in terms of reduced all-cause mortality, cardiovascular events, and improved FMD. The addition of progesterone in MHT does not alter its effects. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore the optimal duration of MHT treatment.

Title: Women’s midlife health: the unfinished research agenda
Journal: Women's Midlife Health
Publication Year: 2023
Diseases: Autoimmune diseases, Cancer, Heart disease

Sample size: 0
The research paper concludes that there are significant gaps in scientific knowledge regarding menopause, reproductive aging, and midlife health, necessitating further research and attention. The authors stress the importance of ongoing studies to address these gaps and enhance understanding in areas like ovarian aging, menopausal symptoms, health risks in diverse populations, and the impact of structural racism on women’s health. They highlight the significance of translating research findings into interventions and education to improve health outcomes in midlife women.

Title: Multiple treatments with human embryonic stem cell-derived mesenchymal progenitor cells preserved the fertility and ovarian function of perimenopausal mice undergoing natural aging
Journal: Stem Cell Research & Therapy
Publication Year: 2024
Diseases: Premature Ovarian Insufficiency, Ovarian Senescence, Ovarian Fibrosis
Location: CHA University
Gender: FEMALE
Sample size: 0
The main conclusion derived from the study is that multiple introductions of hESC-MPCs can improve ovarian environment and reservoir by reducing inflammation and fibrosis through the downregulation of MDSC production in bone marrow. This approach extended fertility and fecundity in perimenopausal female mice by preserving ovarian function. The study suggests that hESC-MPCs could be beneficial for preserving ovarian function in naturally aging females, emphasizing the need for further research for clinical application.

Title: No sex-specific difference in disease trajectory in multiple sclerosis patients before and after age 50

Publication Year: 2013
Diseases: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
Location: Partners Multiple Sclerosis Center, Department of Neurology, Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Northeastern United States
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 551
The study found no interaction between age and sex suggestive of an effect of reproductive aging on clinical or radiologic progression in MS patients. Despite age-related changes in disease severity, the study did not observe a differential impact of menopause on disease trajectory. The authors suggest the need for prospective analyses across the menopausal transition to further understand the potential effects of menopause on MS progression.

Title: Effects of Bilberry and Oat intake on lipids, inflammation and exercise capacity after Acute Myocardial Infarction (BIOAMI): study protocol for a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial
Journal: Trials
Publication Year: 2021
Diseases: Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI), Cardiovascular Disease (CVD)
Location: Sweden
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 900
Utilizing diet supplementation with bilberry and oat products post-AMI may offer additional benefits in lowering LDL cholesterol and inflammation levels, potentially improving exercise capacity. The study aims to provide evidence for the efficacy of these dietary strategies as a cost-effective and safe approach for secondary prevention after AMI. The paper states, "If bilberry and/or oat, in addition to standard medical therapy, can lower LDL cholesterol and inflammation more than standard therapy alone, this could be a cost-effective and safe dietary strategy for secondary prevention after AMI."

Title: Microbiota, type 2 diabetes and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease: protocol of an observational study
Journal: Journal of Translational Medicine
Publication Year: 2019
Diseases: Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD), Type 2 Diabetes (T2D)
Location: South Tyrol, Italy
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 356
The study protocol aimed to investigate the relationship between microbiota alterations, type 2 diabetes, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. By examining participants with and without T2D, the study observed higher prevalence of hepatic steatosis and increased liver stiffness in T2D individuals. This suggests a potential link between T2D and NAFLD. The completion of microbiota analysis is expected to enhance the understanding of these associations.

The Fasting In diabetes Treatment (FIT) trial aims to evaluate the effects of intermittent use of a fasting-mimicking diet in type 2 diabetes patients. Title: Exercise Interventions Improved Sleep Quality through Regulating Intestinal Microbiota Composition
Journal: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
Publication Year: 2022
Diseases: Sleep Disorders
Location: Kunming Medical University
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 22
The study concludes that exercise intervention plays a crucial role in modifying the diversity and composition of the gut microbiota in individuals with sleep disorders, thereby improving sleep quality. The abundance changes of specific beneficial bacteria like Blautia and Eubacterium hallii after exercise intervention were linked to enhanced sleep quality. This suggests a relationship between gut flora composition, exercise, and sleep quality, emphasizing the potential of exercise as a tool to positively influence gut health and sleep patterns.

Title: Human and rat gut microbiome composition is maintained following sleep restriction
Journal: PNAS
Publication Year: 2017
Diseases: Metabolic diseases such as obesity and diabetes
Location: University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
Gender: BOTH

The gut microbiome of both rats and humans showed resilience to short-term sleep restriction, with no significant dysbiotic changes observed. Sleep loss and microbial dysbiosis may have independent effects on the development of metabolic diseases.

metadata.text:
Title: Associations of gut microbiome richness and diversity with objective and subjective sleep measures in a population sample
Journal: Sleep
Publication Year: 2023
Diseases: Sleep apnea
Location: Not Available
Gender: BOTH
Sample size: 0
There is an association between sleep patterns and the composition of the gut microbiome in adults. Adverse sleep measures were linked to lower alpha-diversity, while positive sleep measures were associated with increased alpha-diversity. The findings suggest the potential impact of modifiable health habits, like sleep, on shaping the gut microbiome, which could have implications for overall health.
